number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2013
												[From a previously-written blog post in February, 2013.  It concerns only the first "Episode" and will be updated to include reflection covering the second.]Kentucky Route Zero is a point-and-click adventure game, reminiscent of recent indie success, Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP. It’s presented in a flat-3D sort of style, and features an ambient-y, hymn-y, bluegrass-y soundtrack.For the hour and a half after I turned out my light and sat down, I was absolutely glued to my monitor. I feel that going into details about this game would do anyone’s experience with it a disservice. Just know that it focuses a bit more on exploration than difficult puzzle solving, and from what I can tell, there’s no ‘wrong answer,’ despite having a lot of choices with some of the dialogue paths. So try to be honest with it and not worry about ‘losing.’ I know for sure that I missed at least some content on my first playthrough, so I’ll definitely be revisiting this first part of the game. I think it’s best to go into this one with as little specific expectations as possible.The first Act of Kentucky Route Zero is a charming, unnerving, and at times stressful experience, and easily my first must-play game for 2013.Also, there’s a tech-demo-turned-‘companion-piece’ available called Limits & Demonstrations floating around. It’s free, and acts as a pretty good introduction to the ‘vibe’ of Kentucky Route Zero, its gameplay, engine, and some of the internal ‘lore’ of the game world. It -might- take 10 minutes to get through, so there’s no reason not to check it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												UPDATED May 19th, 2014 (YES):Changed my point of view after playing episode 3 and remembering why I fell in love with this game. Minor spoiler: lovely music show. Simple and marvelous. Truly divine gameplay.This game is an adventure/exploration game with simple yet very stilysh graphics, no voiceover but plenty of atmosphere through music and the way it plays. Even if the technical aspects are simple, they exude lots of charm and style that really integrate well with the game´s goal. Your task is to find Route Zero and make a final deliver. During the game you are going to meet several persons and locations using your truck and a onscreen map to guide you. The way the game is drawn makes you feel like you are about to embark on a 60´s wild journey. Several things are stylized  beaultifully. Do no expect violence or quick time events or even puzzles per se. You are about to embark on a mind blowing experience.This game is so unique that you play with the perspective of several different actors playing thorugh scenes. Expect anything to happen on this fabulous world (anything really), expect several wow moments, expect to think about the significance of what is going on the screen. Great game to play alone in a quiet environment at night to enjoy the music and the game´s atmosphere. Whenever I started an episode I couldn´t stop it until its end.The only downside I can tell is that this game is supposed to be released in five episodes however it took more than an entire year between episodes 2 and 3. I would have to warn you that you will be gambling if you buy this game.because we can never know if and when we are going to get all five episodes released.ORIGINAL REVIEW (NO):I would like to start by saying that even though this game looks simple, it has a distinct artistic feeling to it and it is quite fun to play and sometimes you may even think you are high on some kind of drug. This is a point and click episodic game with plenty of atmosphere and no voice over.I cannot recommend this game because you are going to pay for five episodes and only get two of them. I am waiting for episode 3 for more than an year and I have no clue when of even if it is ever going to be released. As I am most likely stuck with an incomplete game, even if the experience is very interesting, I simply cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Kentucky Route Zero has the best use of atmopshere I've ever seen in a game. While most of the time atmosphere in games is equated to "spoopy dark hallways", KY0 uses solid, washed out colors and wide camera angles to make its world seem desolate and distant.This aesthetic lends a lot of emotional weight to the game's story about the mudane lives of people dealing with poverty. The writing is excellent, especially that of the dialogue. All of the conversation is very mellow, but hints very effectively at the unsaid ways the characters feel. The dialogue trees are also done excellently. They're not about checking off little variables and affecting the game later, they allow you to make little decisions about what kind of people the characters are. It's more like being a part of the storytelling than choosing a path.Unlike many other "story-focused games", KY0 has a sense of brevity. The pacing is excellent, 3 hours went by faster than a couple minutes of RPG exposition. Nothing feels cliche and every line is well-thought out. I don't think I've ever seen a game be more poigniant.This is usually where I'd say that you shouldn't get this is you're looking for a traditional game, but that's not true. You should at least try it, it's more than just a fun waste of time. The $25 price-point is a little steep, though. As of writing the game is on sale for $12.50, but that's only for a day and a half. Another thing to note is that KY0 has only has 2 of a planned 5 acts completed, and there's no guarantee the next 3 will maintain this level of quality. Still, I definately recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Interactive late-night thought stimulator, not quite a game of systems, moreso a beautiful example of games in shortform--beat poetry for our usual, super-adorned and over-budgeted epics. Very George Saunders, not as much David Lynch (surreal yet not really grotesque or terrifying on any level), altogether an audiovisual treat of poetry.A sense of curiosity and some openness is all you need; familiarity with strange art and strange situations not required. Playing in the late hours with headphones is recommended, as is driving the mine tram in Act I with the lights off. Looking forward to further Acts.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Three acts in and this continues to get better and stranger.  The game plays like an odd dream, constantly changing shape and presenting you with the mundane in a new situation.  At one point you're told to retune your radio until you hear something that sounds strange because of how almost familiar it is, and that's everything about this game.It's not going to be for everyone: it's slow, and I could see how someone who wasn't buying into it could find it boring or weird for weird's sake, but if you come to it with an open mind and an acceptance that you're not going to understand everything, this is an outstanding piece of fiction and an outstanding game.Act IV can't come soon enough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Kentucky Route Zero trancends it's genre, it's not just a Point & Click game, it is an experience. The atmosphere provides a stark and beautiful backdrop for the narrative. The adventure on which you embark is in itself both dreamlike and nightmareish making it hard to stop playing once you've taken the plunge. Not only is this an amazing game and a step that shows us that narrative gameplay is a viable option but it also shows us that episodic gameplay works as well. It's a great system to release a game with. The only painful part is waiting for the next episode but it also gives us more time to be excited about it.TLDR: 9/10; would reccomend, narrative games are sweet and so is episodic content.

												  Imagine if a game had the same storytelling skills as Tell Tale mixed with an impossible to re-create indie vibe. That would make the perfect game which just so happens to be a masterpiece called Kentucky Route Zero. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I would definitely recommend this game. The only thing you have to know is that it's not a conventional game. It's more like a surreal interactive storytelling experience. We start the game with the objective of delivering something (we don't know what) to someone (we don't know who). The only problem is that we are lost and that we need to find the "Zero". So basically, the desire line of the game is about finding a way. And we soon realize that the objective is not about the delivery anymore, but just about finding ways. And you have to agree to wander off with the people that you meet on the road in order to find your way again. And it gets very strange.This game is interesting because of the advanced narrative, the master storytelling and the unique experience that it provides. It is beautiful visually, yet very simple. The soundtrack creates a warm and dreamy atmosphere. You will definitely get caught in the universe of this game.I'm not a hardcore gamer and when I play to a game, it's not about performance or achievements. It's about storytelling, visuals and characters. I like to be part of something different than my own reality. And this game is all about that, so I was very pleased.I can't wait for the next episodes to come out!PRO:- We meet characters and we feel like we really share an adventure with them.CON:- Our choices never seem to have real consequences on the game, other than building our own perception of what we're doing (which I guess is the point of the game). So far, we have the feeling that we are progressing, but we don't know if it's towards a resolution, because the mystery only gets thicker. And I wonder how it will unfold. The risk with a surreal narrative is that an abstract adventure could lead to an abstract conclusion. But there is no need to speculate as the rest of the game is yet to be released! And I am definitely hooked. 9/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												If you want a "game" that really sticks with you months after you've played it you want this game. I can talk up the art style or the pacing or the seriousness with which you'll shape your characters (yeah, you control the personalities of characters...I don't know if this changes the plot but committing to one choice over another will change you) or the occasionally breathtaking sound but I won't.I'll just say that this is one of the most memorable gaming experiences I've had and that I've never seen anything else like it, plus we get three more episodes of surprises. If you're a stickler for actual challenge or the dollar/hour ratio or other soulless criteria you might hate this game, so bug off. If you're a fan of unique and personal experiences and burnt out on doing the same-old-same-old in games and just need a mental break, and you don't own this, you have a problem and you need to fix it with Kentucky Route Zero.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												As a Kentuckian and a patron of the arts, Kentucky Route Zero has quickly become one of my favorite indy games. One part existentialist play, one part art piece, and one part point-and-click adventure, it's incredible how much this one game manages to pack in without being too much to handle. Every part of the game is in-depth and interesting from the conversations, the interactive "sets", and the characters themselves. The minimalist art design and the vague, often melancholy/mysterious dialogue compliment each other perfectly giving the game its signature feel which is really undescribable. Upon multiple playthroughs, one finds that the different conversation choices available can drastically change the experience and mood of the game; not from the technical standpoint but more the emotional experience of the player.While not a fast or necessarily exciting game gameplay-wise, various types of interesting and fun gameplay are introduced early on and continue throughout the different acts of KRZ. Examples of these gameplay styles being the character-oriented gameplay, travel gameplay, and perhaps the most fascinating of all, traveling on the Zero. These gameplay styles tie into the story which is exciting in its complexity and immersiveness, new sub-plots are constantly introduced keeping the game fresh. The often loose ends of these sub-plots, mentioned briefly perhaps in a passing conversation, give the characters depth and mystery. I find myself lost within the world of KRZ every time I play and am almost tempted to drive out on the highways featured within the game (highways I know well) to see if I can find the Zero and explore it myself. 10/10The additional "mini games" free for download, Limits and Demonstrations and The Entertainment, are both equally as intriguing as KRZ itself. While very fast to play, they provide small pieces of possibly important exposition which can be found referenced within KRZ if the player pays attention. The blending of storytelling throughout various games/time periods is genius. Both of these free games contain the same gameplay mechanics of KRZ so they are easy to jump right into after playing the main game. Definitely worth downloading and playing if you have a few minutes and want to expand your knowledge of the KRZ universe.The script for The Entertainment is available for purchase in paperback for a very low price. I bought it and love having a piece of the KRZ universe that I can hold in my hands and read. Really fascinating.

But the production, and in particular the sound design is absolutely incredible. There's some particularly amazing sound design in the mines in the first act, and then while driving in the second act. Also, the old folk songs played by silhouettes invoke an around-the-campfire ambience.Incredible game, through and through. Cannot recommend more.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												A staggeringly atmospheric work; an adventure game that's grown up and seen some hard times, that tells you its story in a raspy voice over a tumbler of whiskey. It does things with the genre that I've never seen done before, and does them well. This is not a challenging game, not a game to beat your head against; this is a game to walk through at a slow pace and enjoy. The faint echoes of the banjo blues will keep you company between sessions, gently calling you back to complete the story.

And that's no mean feat because I am not shy about blasting a creator for being a pretentious deluge of pointless information.Ok, if you like David Lynch, The Adventures of Pete and Pete, Oh Brother Where Art Thou or magic realism you gotta get this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												This game has seen a fair bit of attention, both positive and negative, in the game review community. To address the most negative first, is that the game is ugly and a visual mess. I actually downloaded this game upon sight alone and I must say that the minimalistic, angular style is wonderful. Scenery alone is some of the most striking I've seen in awhile from an indie title. And it all serves the environment and characters of the game, augmenting the surreal world of The Zero. The characters seem at home in a world where ghostly mine music, (literally) endless traffic jams, and giant eagles are as normal as a truck making a delivery. It's a game with a mix of wit, spookiness, and poetry that is unlike anything else I've played. The only negative is that I could not train my brain to not look for puzzles or tricks of other point and click games, but that is wholly a personal perception. I look forward to the next 3 Acts.

												Kentucky Route Zero plays like a traditional point & click adventure game stripped of puzzles with a focus purely on the exploration and story of an Antiques Dealer trying to complete a delivery, and the only way to make to the mysterious location is to take Route Zero. It may sound like a boring premise but as you progress through the game you realize that Route Zero is no ordinary highway, and the gorgeous visuals and excellent story telling lead you through a satisfying adventure through the human psyche, and the developers Cardboard Computer poke at your brain in the best way. Recommended, although as of this writing short and incomplete becaus only 2/5 acts have been released.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												I didn't really know what to expect from this game. I was just attracted to how the game looks (visuals, colors, etc.). Also, I didn't know it was going to be episodic, but it has been wonderful so far. There isn't much "gameplay" as all you do is read people's conversations, artricles, and stories. You guide the character (and also in the main map) to areas by point-and-click with your mouse. As simple as this sounds, it doesn't become a chore guiding your character around or just exploring stuff. What captivated me is the overall mood, atmosphere, feel, and pacing of the game. It gives you time to explore surroundings and what people has to say. And once you're immersed, you'll notice all its quirkiness and, at the same time, its spookiness! There's innovative design, rich storytelling, and wonderful music! Another gem in the steam library.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												I'm not all too familiar with point-and-click games or stories steeped in magical realism, but Kentucky Route Zero is both, and has made me a fan. A bit highbrow and downright esoteric, KRZ isn't for everyone yet still manages to be enjoyable to most--a bit like Journey (thatgamecompany / PS3), in the sense that its story eludes simple or quick understanding. But also like Journey and other similarly abstruse titles, it's easy to sink into KRZ even if just for the cozy moodiness and particularly the pleasantly haunting soundtrack which draws strongly from old bluegrass tunes.

Every scene is so totally mind-bending, atmospheric, filled with wonder and encapsulates what games as a medium are capable of doing. Jake and Tamas at Cardboard Computer might be extra-dimensional creatures pulling new concepts from another time and place. And if so, I love them for it.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												I picked up this game because I found the concept rather intriguing.  A secret highway under Kentucky?  I wasn't sure what to expect but I figured what the heck.The world of Kentucky Route Zero is beautiful and mysterious, full of odd characters and dark, derelict places.  The dialogue is all in text form and that seems to help the ambience.  The gameplay is point and click like the old adventure games however there is not much beyond that.  There are no puzzles to solve or minigames as far as I can tell.  It boils down to an interactive story, albeit one that is told very well.Overall I am torn about this.  The art and music are wonderful but the gameplay itself is very shallow.  If the price is right it might be worth checking out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												If you have ever had a vivid summer-sickness dream, then the febrile fog of Kentucky Route Zero will seem familiar, and the ambient sounds of a hot, humid summer night, downright comforting.  There is nothing remotely creepy in the traditional "scare me senseless" fashion in this game.  But existentially and ontologically, the game is downright haunting.  It is one of those games that follows you around for days,—not the pretzel-logic plot of the game, but the fabric and texture of it, and the deja vu the spare, yet lush, scenery evokes. Deja vu of what? I don't know ,(or more accurately, I don't remember) . . . .Kentucky Route Zero seems to inhabit the realim of parallel uniiverses and Zen koans.  If you like Kairo, then it's highly likely that you will like KRO.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I would definitely recommend this game. The only thing you have to know is that it's not a conventional game. It's more like a surreal interactive storytelling experience. We start the game with the objective of delivering something (we don't know what) to someone (we don't know who). The only problem is that we are lost and that we need to find the "Zero". So basically, the desire line of the game is about finding a way. And we soon realize that the objective is not about the delivery anymore, but just about finding ways. And you have to agree to wander off with the people that you meet on the road in order to find your way again. And it gets very strange.This game is interesting because of the advanced narrative, the master storytelling and the unique experience that it provides. It is beautiful visually, yet very simple. The soundtrack creates a warm and dreamy atmosphere. You will definitely get caught in the universe of this game.I'm not a hardcore gamer and when I play to a game, it's not about performance or achievements. It's about storytelling, visuals and characters. I like to be part of something different than my own reality. And this game is all about that, so I was very pleased.I can't wait for the next episodes to come out!PRO:- We meet characters and we feel like we really share an adventure with them.CON:- Our choices never seem to have real consequences on the game, other than building our own perception of what we're doing (which I guess is the point of the game). So far, we have the feeling that we are progressing, but we don't know if it's towards a resolution, because the mystery only gets thicker. And I wonder how it will unfold. The risk with a surreal narrative is that an abstract adventure could lead to an abstract conclusion. But there is no need to speculate as the rest of the game is yet to be released! And I am definitely hooked. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												It's rare that you find such a beautifully-conceived work of art here in the world of gaming, but when you do, it's an incredible experience.  This has the feel of a haunting work of literature, and will leave you pondering the meaning of every detail.  This could be dutifully analyzed in an English class and a drama class, as it conveys a narrative through exposition, dialogue, and prose.  I don't want to say too much about it, folks.  Just play it.  Experience it, savor it...it's an atypical piece that is somehow nostalgic yet unfamiliar, grave yet absurd, and tangible yet unreal.  As you can see, this game has caused me to spout poetic praise! So it's not for everyone--heady magical realism is not your typical "game" material, as I alluded to before.  If you don't find those playwrights and authors interesting, than this program might not be your cup of tea.  But if you're a fan....don't miss this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												A hauntingly beautiful jaunt across a landscape that shows only what you need and hides what you need to imagine for yourself. I recommend that you experience this with headphones or a great sound system, in a dark room, with the lights turned off. There's nothing scary, it's just better that way.By the way, this isn't really a game per se, it's more like an idle indie movie that you click on. If you seek puzzles the likes of which Monkey Island offers, this is nothing close. Characters are closer to templates that you build backstories for through dialogue choices, and the real value in the game is interpreting what that means as the world unfurls around them.Given the above, it's totally okay to think it's overpriced, but do make sure it's on your list for the sales season.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I will give this game a guarded recommendation, because although I like it (so far) it seems like way too long between chapters.Kentucky Route Zero is beautiful, surreal, moody, and atmospheric to the max.  More a story than a game, it's about exploration and thoughtful consideration of events as they unfold. Creepy moments serve to keep you interested, which is important because there are no puzzles, no conflict and only the barest thread of a narrative. That means it's not everybody's cup of tea.The only tension is whether your decisions and dialogue choices have really made any difference. For example, I think one of my decisions caused my character to develop a limp when he otherwise might not have. Who knows, I'll have to play it again.So to sum up: beautiful game/story, not for everyone, well worth the sale price, concerned how long between chapters.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Kentucky Route Zero has the best use of atmopshere I've ever seen in a game. While most of the time atmosphere in games is equated to "spoopy dark hallways", KY0 uses solid, washed out colors and wide camera angles to make its world seem desolate and distant.This aesthetic lends a lot of emotional weight to the game's story about the mudane lives of people dealing with poverty. The writing is excellent, especially that of the dialogue. All of the conversation is very mellow, but hints very effectively at the unsaid ways the characters feel. The dialogue trees are also done excellently. They're not about checking off little variables and affecting the game later, they allow you to make little decisions about what kind of people the characters are. It's more like being a part of the storytelling than choosing a path.Unlike many other "story-focused games", KY0 has a sense of brevity. The pacing is excellent, 3 hours went by faster than a couple minutes of RPG exposition. Nothing feels cliche and every line is well-thought out. I don't think I've ever seen a game be more poigniant.This is usually where I'd say that you shouldn't get this is you're looking for a traditional game, but that's not true. You should at least try it, it's more than just a fun waste of time. The $25 price-point is a little steep, though. As of writing the game is on sale for $12.50, but that's only for a day and a half. Another thing to note is that KY0 has only has 2 of a planned 5 acts completed, and there's no guarantee the next 3 will maintain this level of quality. Still, I definately recommend it.

												Interactive late-night thought stimulator, not quite a game of systems, moreso a beautiful example of games in shortform--beat poetry for our usual, super-adorned and over-budgeted epics. Very George Saunders, not as much David Lynch (surreal yet not really grotesque or terrifying on any level), altogether an audiovisual treat of poetry.A sense of curiosity and some openness is all you need; familiarity with strange art and strange situations not required. Playing in the late hours with headphones is recommended, as is driving the mine tram in Act I with the lights off. Looking forward to further Acts.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is a 5 part series of point and click adventure style games, of which, 2 have been released. The game has a wonderful artistic style and appeals to me in a way to keep me going throughout. I had one minor graphical glitch however, regarding the v-sync, where if v-sync was turned off, the game does not scroll properly, making navigating screens difficult. I recommend leaving the v-sync on for this reason.The game is not terribly long if you don't want to navigate away from the main storyline. The majority of the side stories are all self-guided/discovered and typically 100% reading. Spend some time traveling around and finding things. It adds to the story. I would recommend this game on the graphical fidelity alone, but it is well written too. Play!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												David Lynch's "Twin Peaks" meets the Lucas Arts classic "Full Throttle" meets Beckett's "Waiting for Godot" meets an ingenous DIY play texture with a rich and carefully plotted story. This game MUST be played with headphones, in the dark, with utter concentration. "Kentucky Route Zero" is not taxing in the twitchy way you might experience a FPS, it's an engrossing and whole body experience; by the time you're done with the story's third act, you'll be exhaling cold, damp cave air. A wonderful game that — for enjoyment — requires attention to details and an open mind. What sets this one apart, is that KR-0 will not provide you with obvious feedback. There's no health bar, for example. The 2D map (a central interface in the first part of the story) is somewhat unreliable and appears, at times, to be working against you. And, well, things get sort of meta-exploratory from there. Open mind, I said. Oh, and Junebug, Junebug, Junebug.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												A hauntingly beautiful jaunt across a landscape that shows only what you need and hides what you need to imagine for yourself. I recommend that you experience this with headphones or a great sound system, in a dark room, with the lights turned off. There's nothing scary, it's just better that way.By the way, this isn't really a game per se, it's more like an idle indie movie that you click on. If you seek puzzles the likes of which Monkey Island offers, this is nothing close. Characters are closer to templates that you build backstories for through dialogue choices, and the real value in the game is interpreting what that means as the world unfurls around them.Given the above, it's totally okay to think it's overpriced, but do make sure it's on your list for the sales season.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game is worth playing just for the stunning graphics and atmospheric soundtrack alone. But the gameplay is also worthwhile. KRZ is a winding point-and-click adventure that plays out like an interactive fiction, full of mystery and intrigue. The game has a very melancholy tone, that might also be described as nostalgic or maybe even spiritual. The writing is superb. The characters in KRZ all have their own background story that reveals itself gradually throughout the episodes. If you want to take a journey inside yourself and simultaneously venture into another world that exists above and beyond you current reality, while still not being that different from reality at all, then this game will be a treat for you. Traveling the Zero itself reminds me of the cult film Donnie Darko, which is also a surreal story involving alternate realities - so if you like that movie, chances are you'll love this game. The downside of this game is that the episodes are somewhat slow to be released - there are still two unreleased episodes in the works, and we will probably still be waiting a while for those. Overall, KRZ is unlike any other game I have ever played - it's refreshing, engaging, and oddly comforting. And I recommend it to everyone who enjoys an odd mystery. EDIT: I just realized while reading another review that you can also access the full songs from the soundtrack to this game within the install folder. It's included with the purchase of the game, which is great.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												It's hard to talk about KRZ without spoiling the experience. The experience, however, is second to none. It's short, Act I is about an hour and a half long, and that's what I've played so far plus a brief portion of Act II. The attention to detail is impecable and you'll stumble across something and wonder how it wasn't obvious it was there the entire time. It's a point and click, and it's exploration driven but it's not about exploring the game as much as it is about exploring who you are within the game.Again, it's hard to explain about spoiling the magic, so lets just say the game progresses in a way unlike any other story driven game I've played and it makes you feel not just an observer of the game, but an integral part of the story. This is one of the rare titles that has been around for a while but the deepest I've seen it discounted is 50% and that alone intrigued me to pick it up without knowing more than it's critically aclaimed. Up to this point I can say I'm not disappointed with my purchase and I can only see it becoming more worth it as the game unfolds.Finally, this is a game richer than a Godiva Chocolate Cheesecake. You will have to pace yourself :)

Unique, beautiful artwork and a wonderful storyline make Kentucky Route Zero one of the most enjoyable indie games I've played in months. Gameplay is smooth, but nothing to write home about, esspecially the awkward functionality of the hub map which gets you to the next bit of story. As for the story, I will leave that for whomever's reading this to experience themselves, but prepare to be engaged.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												We're only three acts in, but I feel compelled to write a review about Kentucky Route Zero regardless. It's an adventure game, of course, but it eschews the puzzle-solving component of most of those games to instead provide an atmospheric, choose-your-own-adventure style of storytelling.  It's gloriously weird and wonderful.To me, which makes the game so appealing, there is this enduring creepiness about everything in the game; the fact that the day always seems to stand at the edge of dusk contributes to that fact.  This creepiness lies on a balance teetering toward understanding, pushes you on to learn more about the Zero, and continue onward.Anyway, despite this somewhat pretentious-sounding rambling, Cardboard Computer has a winner here. Give it a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Kentucky is now on my top-list of favourite games. A mysterious "Lynchian" world that I can't wait to dig-in further.The art direction has a unique, fascinating, style. Crafted using simple 3D assets and glorified with a smart usage of lighting, camera depths and "layers".The story is driven with smart-written dialogs that invite you to wonder what are the motivations and backstories of each of those characters.<Chapter I> Great introduction to the main character, and his dog. Sometimes wondering if this is all "real" or part of a "dream", you keep moving forward in this sort of "ghost story". Maybe none of the previous guesses is right, and the main character is just high on LSD. But something odd is going on, and you want to know what is it.<Chapter II> The story keeps growing up your interest. The Museum and Forest scenes are brilliant, both visually and script-wise. The fact that these scenes are built from the point of view of other characters, adds an unbelievable depth to the personality of your main character.<Chapter III> The worst chapter so far. It's sort of boring, as you never understand where are you leading to. Or what's your objective. Too much text, too few awesome visuals. I hope this is just the prelude for an amazing Chapter IV. Where I'll be able to understand what happened in the 3rd. Get back on my excitement for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Kentucky Route Zero is something special. It's more of an experience than a game. It conveys a certain dreamlike atmosphere and puts you in a certain state of mind unlike any other game I've played. It's very peaceful, though at the same time carrying a subtle undercurrent of social commentary on topics like crushing debt, home forclosure, and alcoholism. It's chock full of literary references (detailed here[superlevel.de] and here[superlevel.de]), most of which sailed right over my head, but it's still a fantastic experience for the atmosphere and writing alone. The interesting and rich characters you meet, the crickets chirping into the night, the music, it's all just absolutely beautiful. It's not for everyone - it's definitely deliberately paced, and there isn't really any action or puzzles to speak of. If you dislike games like Gone Home or Dear Esther solely because they're "not games" (regardless of content) then this probably isn't for you. But if you can keep an open mind, you'll be treated to an experience unlike any other.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												Kentucky Route Zero is a lot like being home. The environments have a pseudo-surrealist/realist feel to them much like the of Twin Peaks if you are familiar to the popular cult show. It has a unique style that scratches an itch that few things can satisify. So, just on how well this game conveys tone and world building alone makes it recomendable.It's a simple adventure game that follows the likes of Telltale's the walking dead, it isn't so much about puzzle solving but about the relationship of the characters and how much involvement you decide as a player to invest in the story. But instead, you don't just control the actions of one character you often switch to many different character's perspective and you get a sense of being not just a passive reader, a recipient, of a story but as a writer or an actor too. It's a nice feeling, because everyone is likable and there is a lot of heart and love in the backstories of the characters however simple they may seem. They're just good folk. You can tell the developers of this game have a passion for play writting style because a lot of the scenes come off as stage directions which give the exchanges a unique feel.I feel we are on the brink of redefining what the term video games mean. Of course video games really well describes what the first iteration of games look like, things like pacman or space invaders where there are clearly expressed winstates and scoreboards. But, as the medium has matured we have gotten narrative focused games like Bioshock or even something like Metal of Honor/Call of Duty, where it is implied but not really that winining the game is by finishing all the narative content. And, now we are even in more obscure territory with things like Kentucky Route Zero or Dear Esther and Proteus, where the process of calling them 'games' seems almost silly. This could be the start of something, maybe a new medium, or a change of definition. In any case KR0 is a good example of the expanding definition of this genre of "non-games" that has suddenly gained popularity.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Kentucky Route Zero is something special. It's more of an experience than a game. It conveys a certain dreamlike atmosphere and puts you in a certain state of mind unlike any other game I've played. It's very peaceful, though at the same time carrying a subtle undercurrent of social commentary on topics like crushing debt, home forclosure, and alcoholism. It's chock full of literary references (detailed here[superlevel.de] and here[superlevel.de]), most of which sailed right over my head, but it's still a fantastic experience for the atmosphere and writing alone. The interesting and rich characters you meet, the crickets chirping into the night, the music, it's all just absolutely beautiful. It's not for everyone - it's definitely deliberately paced, and there isn't really any action or puzzles to speak of. If you dislike games like Gone Home or Dear Esther solely because they're "not games" (regardless of content) then this probably isn't for you. But if you can keep an open mind, you'll be treated to an experience unlike any other.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Among a slew of poorly realised, narrative driven indie games which critics praise for story, Kentucky Route Zero truly stands out as a masterstroke. Cinematic, literary, and 5 years ahead of its time, it is unique insofar as it is written by actual writers. Give it a couple years and this will be the seminal text in a new genre of literary study. If you want to write for games, play this first. Then read some books.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Kentucky Route Zero has the best use of atmopshere I've ever seen in a game. While most of the time atmosphere in games is equated to "spoopy dark hallways", KY0 uses solid, washed out colors and wide camera angles to make its world seem desolate and distant.This aesthetic lends a lot of emotional weight to the game's story about the mudane lives of people dealing with poverty. The writing is excellent, especially that of the dialogue. All of the conversation is very mellow, but hints very effectively at the unsaid ways the characters feel. The dialogue trees are also done excellently. They're not about checking off little variables and affecting the game later, they allow you to make little decisions about what kind of people the characters are. It's more like being a part of the storytelling than choosing a path.Unlike many other "story-focused games", KY0 has a sense of brevity. The pacing is excellent, 3 hours went by faster than a couple minutes of RPG exposition. Nothing feels cliche and every line is well-thought out. I don't think I've ever seen a game be more poigniant.This is usually where I'd say that you shouldn't get this is you're looking for a traditional game, but that's not true. You should at least try it, it's more than just a fun waste of time. The $25 price-point is a little steep, though. As of writing the game is on sale for $12.50, but that's only for a day and a half. Another thing to note is that KY0 has only has 2 of a planned 5 acts completed, and there's no guarantee the next 3 will maintain this level of quality. Still, I definately recommend it.

												Interactive late-night thought stimulator, not quite a game of systems, moreso a beautiful example of games in shortform--beat poetry for our usual, super-adorned and over-budgeted epics. content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I will give this game a guarded recommendation, because although I like it (so far) it seems like way too long between chapters.Kentucky Route Zero is beautiful, surreal, moody, and atmospheric to the max.  More a story than a game, it's about exploration and thoughtful consideration of events as they unfold. Creepy moments serve to keep you interested, which is important because there are no puzzles, no conflict and only the barest thread of a narrative. That means it's not everybody's cup of tea.The only tension is whether your decisions and dialogue choices have really made any difference. For example, I think one of my decisions caused my character to develop a limp when he otherwise might not have. Who knows, I'll have to play it again.So to sum up: beautiful game/story, not for everyone, well worth the sale price, concerned how long between chapters.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												 It's strange how sometimes playing a game relates so deeply with your current situation that it feels as though it was made specifically for you at that moment. You get a pit in your stomach and when you stop playing you see the world in a whole new light. Perspective changes and you just feel as though a weight has been lifted off of you when you turn your attention away from the screen after that last pivotal plot point. Personally I am going through an extended transition from previous Military experience, then school, and now a professional career with a family, life can be pretty confusing. That confusion has nothing on Kentucky Route Zero by developer Cardboard Computer. There are words that can describe the game: surreal, strange, odd, uncanny, bizarre. You can describe the things that happen in the story by sequence, but completing the ideas as to how or why these things happen is impossible. The game itself isn't so much a game as a series of events that captures you and allows you to shape the adventure and it's contents as a concept of your own design. The events are all going to happen regardless of whether or not you make certain choices, the only thing that may change are dialogue options and responses. You even begin to have conversations with yourself through multiple characters gradually. This is interesting because now both sides of the conversation have different possibilities, and somehow the conversations seem less mechanical even if they are with yourself. Going back to describing the game, there are words to describe it, but each of those words seem to have connotations that don't fully encompass the ideas portrayed. The feeling is fuller, than those words can describe. It's very odd, and I don't want to give any of it away as a spoiler. Things that are strange and unbelievable happen and the characters seem to take it with a grain of salt. Things like traveling on an inter-dimensional highway with arbitrary markers made of everyday items, replacing a leg with a metal skeleton prosthesis (and not reacting), taking a shot with a skeleton with a tape recorder, flying on a giant eagle that moves houses daily. These are all taken by the characters as something completely acceptable if a bit odd. No explanation of why these things are happening, just that they do.  There is no time or place to explore why these things happen, so taking them with stride is forced on the player as well as the characters. You can only move forward and there are no places to take breaks to look for answers. So you derive the answers from events as they move along, and accept what doesn't make sense, and just move along. Eventually events in the story that didn't make sense are after the fact, and become a part of the plot. So even surreal happenings can become important regardless of how illogical or insane they seem at first. The entire interface is a point and click adventure, but there are only so many things you can point and click on and they are all labeled for convenience and to keep the story moving at a reasonable pace. This doesn't detract from the experience, as the game itself is surreal enough to keep you entertained. If anything it keeps things interesting as you always want to move forward to see what strange happenings are next. The strange is the spectacle. And the glass through which you look is your own mind. The experience is engrossing. You'll like this game if: You enjoy M.C. Escher and Picasso, and want to play a game designed by them. Strictly for those though that enjoy being told a story, and not necessarily molding it. My review blog where I review games that I play from my steam library is here: http://bigdadgamer.blogspot.com/

												A staggeringly atmospheric work; an adventure game that's grown up and seen some hard times, that tells you its story in a raspy voice over a tumbler of whiskey. It does things with the genre that I've never seen done before, and does them well. This is not a challenging game, not a game to beat your head against; this is a game to walk through at a slow pace and enjoy. The faint echoes of the banjo blues will keep you company between sessions, gently calling you back to complete the story.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Experience on Linux so far:+ Solid.The game:Hm. I don't exactly know what genre to put it in, because it deviates quite a lot from the normal point-and-click adventures. You direct the narration and progress the story line using dialogs of your choosing. Although some critisize the game for the fact that dialog choices do not (seemlingly) affect the outcome. What dialogs I choose matters to me, my mindset as a player, which is good enough for me. The artwork is beautiful and unique, the story and dialogs are engaging and sometimes emotional in the most subtle of ways. You may not know why, but sometimes you get a discomforting or straight out creepy feeling as you guide the main characters through the game. Likewise, some scenes are very endearing.With proper voice actors (the game has no voice acting, only text dialogs) this game would have been gold.The game is released in three acts (2 are out so far) and I have to deduct points from the overall score because the releases have been few and far in between. I recommend you wait until all acts are released before you purchase, I was very unhappy with the waiting time for act 2 and act 3.I'm not sure I like this trend started by that very famous game title based on a comic book about zombies, but the game is worth a buy.Score:3/5

												It's hard to talk about KRZ without spoiling the experience. The experience, however, is second to none. It's short, Act I is about an hour and a half long, and that's what I've played so far plus a brief portion of Act II. The attention to detail is impecable and you'll stumble across something and wonder how it wasn't obvious it was there the entire time. This is one of the rare titles that has been around for a while but the deepest I've seen it discounted is 50% and that alone intrigued me to pick it up without knowing more than it's critically aclaimed. Up to this point I can say I'm not disappointed with my purchase and I can only see it becoming more worth it as the game unfolds.Finally, this is a game richer than a Godiva Chocolate Cheesecake. Posted: November 24, 2016
												Kentucky Route Zero has been and is an experience that I greatly recommend. In a way I suppose I could describe it as one of the most meaning works I have been exposed to in the last few years and even after finishing the latest episode, it still haunts me. Think Undertale but instead of a dagger in your heart, it's a semi-automatic rifle that unloads an entire ammo-clip into your mind whenever you finish reading a sentence. Poetic without being pretentious and sombre without feeling draggy, KRZ is the most well-rounded work I've seen that spans across various discplines in the arts and probably will see in a long time.10/10, tailor made for philosophy junkies and can incur an existential crisis.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Kentucky Route Zero is a bit different.-A large part of it is reading meandering prose. -It's deliberately paced on the slow side. -There isn't a whole lot of 'gameplay' other than very straightforward point-and-click.   If I didn't value the game's unconventional narrative, or excellent characterisation, or awesome synergy between great visual and sound design, then these could be negative criticisms but instead each of the above contributes to the game's unique aesthetic; a wonderful sense of dreamlike wandering. The events of this game play out like a dream also, getting increasingly disconnected, esoteric and more surreal. The divergence in the narrative dependent on your choices only adds to its warrenous feel as you begin to explore the americana present in the Zero and try to get to grips with how far the rabbit hole goes.Like a half-remembered dream Kentucky Route Zero somehow holds together as more than the sum of its parts and leaves me wishing more games were half as experimental.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Sometimes when you're flying through space you end up meeting a robot. Sometimes that robot is wearing a dress and rides a motorcycle with another robot. Sometimes that robot plays the keytar and likes to sing in dive bars. Sometimes that robot knows the entire history and future of the world in which you live. Sometimes that robot is Lieutenant Commander Data. These scientificially observed facts are called Scalzi's laws of robotics. A robot can only be one of those four things. Kentucky Route Zero is a game that explores what it might mean for the laws of robotics to be slightly relaxed (not unlike how Star Trek slightly relaxes the intergalactic speed limit), allowing a robot to be multiple types of robot at the same time. That's right, in Kentucky Route Zero, Lieutenant Commander Data puts on a dress, picks up a keytar and plans your destiny from his dive bar. This is a wonderful game that really makes you think about the universe and doesn't contain any disturbing skeletons.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I don't really know how to describe this game except that it probably isn't quite what you're expecting, in a good way. I believe it's been classified as an interactive narrative rather than a game. Interaction is based around moving the main character within the scenes and opening dialogue with others. The dialogue will change based on which response you choose, however you cannot truly alter the outcomes of each segment.The strong points within this story are the art direction and audio by far, it's quite fantastic. I feel the largest drawback with this game as it continues development is the absence of puzzles, even simple ones. I think there was just one in the very beginning, you had to retrieve an item for an old man. This allowed interaction between the main character and the environment, which is almost completely missing now.I can't really describe the experience of this, for most I suspect it will mystify and be quite eerie....maybe even sad at points. I enjoy that it's designed that way because there are so few games or interactive narratives that are. If you were to ask me what to expect from this, I don't know what to say....you're in for a great surprise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												This interactive story is very engaging. The plot is elusive, but not for lack of substance, but rather a poetic metering of details. The delivery of the story focuses on imagery and character interaction, and to some extent on the characters themselves. Very abstract, but it really gets to you. I live right in the middle of the setting of the game, and the overmap represents the region very well (in an abstract way, it is not a true map but the regions are as familiar as home). This makes the descriptions of the different truck stops much more immediate to me, but they are well-crafted on their own.I'm a big fan of this game, definitely recommend it.I finished playing Act III. The mood of this game is so intense! I'm somewhere between 'deeply unsettled' and 'terrified'. I absolutely recommend playing the free interquels you can find on the developer's site kentuckyroutezero.com . They add context to the game's plot and characters, but The Entertainment especially is also a very interesting experience on its own. I know some people have complaints about the slow development schedule, but Cardboard Computer isn't a big dev like Telltale. A game that I'm so enthralled with like Zero is hard to wait for, but Act III blew me away and I'm willing to wait for that kind of quality.The third interquel came out recently and it is just as avant-garde as the second. It takes the form of a phone number, and has already revealed many secrets. It even inspired me to take a trip to my local state park.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												While I've only completed Act II so far, I can safely say that Kentucky Route Zero is one of the most ethereal, engaging experiences I've ever had with digital media. It's hard to call it a game, even in the more non-traditional indie sense. It really is an experiential piece of interactive art, with a delightfully rich, simple though avant-garde art style, an incredible sense of moody, mythical presence, and fantastically engaging dialogue. Play it if you want to experience a game unlike any other, and if you value story and character development over points and explosions.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Easily one of the most amazing and affecting games ever.  Some people claim it's "not a game" because it doesn't have puzzles like a traditional adventure game, but that sells this game short.  The makers definitely don't care what your pre-concieved notions of a "game" might be, but the interactivity is very high but in ways I've never seen before.  You don't so much choose what's going to happen as you craft the characters past while going on this bizarre, amazing journey with them.  The visuals are stark and striking.  The regular soundtrack is equally stark, but subdued.  Where it stands out are the bluegrass songs that suddenly appear out of the blue, like the band playing in the shadows of the foreground in the first act, or the melancholy lone banjo in the forest of the second act.  The third act, in addition to an excellent bluegrass song includes a stunning and unique interactive song that really blew me away.  GET THIS GAME.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												This is a game with a tired and sleepless tone, feeling every bit as nostalgic and vaguely tragic as the memories of a dream that fade away just after waking too early in the morning.  It's like being on the road at night, listening to the hollow drone of cars driving on the freeway, making small talk with an old man at a gas station while you warm up a pre-packaged egg sandwich in the microwave.  You start your car and pull onto the road more out of habit and instinct than desire or necessity, and immediately forget the details of your conversation.As a work of storytelling, it discusses subjects that many storytellers are reticent to approach:  it's a game about getting old; it's a game about trying to forget old demons; it's a game about surviving the long recession of the late 2000s; it's a game about the contradictions of working class culture in America; it's a game about accidental relationships.  No other game that I've played has come this close to talking about our lives in such an honest way.  Don't let yourself pass it by.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												Picked this up largely on a whim, since its OST and visual design struck a chord with me, and everything about it has been above and beyond all expectations.I went into it expecting a point-and-click with some nice art direction and relaxing ambient music. What I got was a enchanting piece of (semi-interactive) theatre filled with nuance and detail; a surreal world filled with intertwining stories and characters, each with something memorable to bring to the fore. Every time a new act has been released, it's been played at 2am with the lights off. I've just completely lost myself in it for a few hours at a time, and it's constantly been on my mind at some level since I first played it in 2013.It's slow-paced and very much non-traditional - it doesn't feature much of the pixel-hunting and puzzle-solving you might expect from a typical adventure game - but the dialogue, worldbuilding, themes and atmosphere carry this game effortlessly. Even something as simple as the movement mechanics are constantly played with to make different sections of the story distinct. Exploration and uncovering the myriad secrets is heavily recommended.Note that the final act has yet to be released, and if previous experience is any indication, it will be a long, long while before it is. However, said experience leaves me with no doubt that it will be worth the wait. If you do check it out, be sure to play the free "Interval" content the developers have also produced. They add much to the mood and lore of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Bizarre and surreal. SCORE: 65/100.This is not The Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us, and neither is it Broken Age or Grim Fandango. It is its own thing, and it does a medoicre job at that. It starts off rather mundanely, but steadily gets weirder and more abstract as it goes. Time and space come in to play in odd ways and you will often be confused, sometimes irritatingly so.This is a strange game, and I'm unsure if it will ever get its fifth act, since it took years for Act IV of a game that looks like it would take a few weeks to make.Act IV was SUPER SLOW and I couldn't even finish it. Just mind-numbingly boring and slow. Changed my review from "Yes" to "No" for recommendation.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I definitely liked the unique art/atmosphere, plus it answers the age-old question of what a more surreal version of Zork would look like. Definitely not for everyone, as it has a slow pace, lacks an exciting plot, has no puzzles, and (I think) doesn't let you affect the narrative in any significant way. In fact, I felt bored for parts of Act III and/or Act IV, perhaps because I insisted on playing through all the Acts in one sitting. On the whole, though, I liked it a lot as a strange, extended mood piece. Hopefully Act V will be interesting, when it comes out.Total playing time for Acts I through IV was six hours. There might be some reply value, but I'm not sure.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												One of my favorite games on Steam. It pushes the boundaries in point and click text adventure genre.Kentucky Route Zero is special. It's surrealistic and it's not an easy plot to grasp like most games. However, for fans of the genre and people who generally like beautiful fantasy stories, this is it. I got the game on Humble Monthly and I didn't knew what it was, I played it without any information and it was such a surprise...Visually gorgeous, a festa to the eyes, and a delight to the ears, each episode is artistically unique. A lot of thought has been put into details, and this makes it a game for you NOT to rush through and get over it. And if you start playing this and you're not sure about it, please try to hold on until episode 3. The concert... omg! What a s-c-e-n-e! ♬ It's too late to love you ♬ As of this review episode 5 is still on the making and I wish the developers the best.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Kentucky Route Zero is a bit different.-A large part of it is reading meandering prose. -It's deliberately paced on the slow side. -There isn't a whole lot of 'gameplay' other than very straightforward point-and-click.   If I didn't value the game's unconventional narrative, or excellent characterisation, or awesome synergy between great visual and sound design, then these could be negative criticisms but instead each of the above contributes to the game's unique aesthetic; a wonderful sense of dreamlike wandering. The events of this game play out like a dream also, getting increasingly disconnected, esoteric and more surreal. The divergence in the narrative dependent on your choices only adds to its warrenous feel as you begin to explore the americana present in the Zero and try to get to grips with how far the rabbit hole goes.Like a half-remembered dream Kentucky Route Zero somehow holds together as more than the sum of its parts and leaves me wishing more games were half as experimental.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Kentucky Route Zero has been and is an experience that I greatly recommend. In a way I suppose I could describe it as one of the most meaning works I have been exposed to in the last few years and even after finishing the latest episode, it still haunts me. Think Undertale but instead of a dagger in your heart, it's a semi-automatic rifle that unloads an entire ammo-clip into your mind whenever you finish reading a sentence. Poetic without being pretentious and sombre without feeling draggy, KRZ is the most well-rounded work I've seen that spans across various discplines in the arts and probably will see in a long time.10/10, tailor made for philosophy junkies and can incur an existential crisis.

												Driving at night; there's something surreal about the whole experience, isn't there? You're just tired enough that the things you see in the corner of your eye take on their own, strange, liminal existence - right where your headlights touch the road, that infinitely thin border between light and dark, wakefulness and dreaming.That's basically what this game evokes. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												Picked this up largely on a whim, since its OST and visual design struck a chord with me, and everything about it has been above and beyond all expectations.I went into it expecting a point-and-click with some nice art direction and relaxing ambient music. What I got was a enchanting piece of (semi-interactive) theatre filled with nuance and detail; a surreal world filled with intertwining stories and characters, each with something memorable to bring to the fore. Every time a new act has been released, it's been played at 2am with the lights off. I've just completely lost myself in it for a few hours at a time, and it's constantly been on my mind at some level since I first played it in 2013.It's slow-paced and very much non-traditional - it doesn't feature much of the pixel-hunting and puzzle-solving you might expect from a typical adventure game - but the dialogue, worldbuilding, themes and atmosphere carry this game effortlessly. Even something as simple as the movement mechanics are constantly played with to make different sections of the story distinct. Exploration and uncovering the myriad secrets is heavily recommended.Note that the final act has yet to be released, and if previous experience is any indication, it will be a long, long while before it is. However, said experience leaves me with no doubt that it will be worth the wait. If you do check it out, be sure to play the free "Interval" content the developers have also produced. They add much to the mood and lore of the game.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Bizarre and surreal. SCORE: 65/100.This is not The Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us, and neither is it Broken Age or Grim Fandango. It is its own thing, and it does a medoicre job at that. It starts off rather mundanely, but steadily gets weirder and more abstract as it goes. Time and space come in to play in odd ways and you will often be confused, sometimes irritatingly so.This is a strange game, and I'm unsure if it will ever get its fifth act, since it took years for Act IV of a game that looks like it would take a few weeks to make.Act IV was SUPER SLOW and I couldn't even finish it. Just mind-numbingly boring and slow. Changed my review from "Yes" to "No" for recommendation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												It is late, and you should be going to bed. But you don't want to. Not yet. You don't have anything important to do, or anything at all, really. But you refuse the gentle beckoning of sleep, your act of continued consciousness a sort of indifferent defiance of human frailty. In those dim hours, the time where nothing is significant and yet everything is important - this game should be played.In light of the recent influx of negative reviews, I felt I should update this review with my own opinion on the matter. I purchased the game shortly after Act Two was released. Was the wait between Act Two and Act Three longer than I would have liked? Yes. But when it was released, I was instantly impressed by how much more impressive the act was than the previous one, in every concievable way, and I had though Acts One and Two had been incredible experiences.Besides, the best way to play this game is with at least a six month gap between Acts. Hazy, half-recalled memories of what happened before... that, my friend, is the heart of Kentucky Route Zero.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												KRZ is a triumph of storytelling and aesthetics. The game falls more on the “interactive fiction” side of the spectrum, as dialogue options serve more to set the tone than to affect outcomes. But this technique is where the game shines - you are allowed to sculpt the histories, intentions, and emotions of the characters. The prose is deft and economical, dancing between playful, philosophical, tender, and unsettling. The pacing is slow and methodical – think a Lynch film – which rewards patience with moments of serene beauty and oppressive sadness.Aesthetically, the game is a slam dunk – gorgeous visuals, minimal design, creative camera work. The music is possibly my favorite part of the game, perfectly augmenting the scenes with a diverse sonic palette, ranging from ambient, musique concrete, bluegrass, and dream pop (whisperwave?).Most impressively, KRZ is alludes to a wide variety of influences, yet somehow pieces them together into a cohesive world. The list is monstrous: southern-gothic fiction, theatrical set design, avant-garde visual art and film, field recordings, magical realism, early text-based adventure games, etc. Yet they are pieced together into a unique arrangement that is greater than the sum of its parts.I think KRZ is a masterpiece.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I don't know if Kentucky Route Zero will be entirely satisfactory. I think currently it gets lumped in with narrative focused games and while that's not entirely inaccurate it also reminds me of late night short foreign movies and performance art and those weird sometimes mesmerising, sometimes grating and repulsive works of art that tend to inspire some pretty strong but not very positive reactions.I think this experience suited me, it wasn't what I expected but then it also wasn't like I had particular expectations beyond a certain kind of atmosphere and maybe some unique visual story telling tools.There is a book called 'The Night Circus' by Erin Morgenstern and its greatest feature is the rich way it references all the senses in a room so often. The book took joy in evoking a moment and location and visual style, it adored whimsy and art and sumptuous beauty. It had an intriguing story and reasonably compelling characters but I believe it was the style of evoking scenes that made it either greatly loved or merely 'pretty good/okay' in people's eyes.Something about that style of experience only appealing to certain people with the inclination for that kind of storytelling makes me think that KR0 is similar? Not in the style of storytelling but in its being not everyone's cup of tea. For some people it's going to make some dissapointing choices with plot and characters that are going to be difficult for them to feel satisfied by despite whatever tonal sense it makes.I'm not saying 'people will cry if there's not happy ending' I guess I'm more saying I don't mind if there's no pay off for some things (good or bad) but other people will (not unreasonably) feel cheated or dissapointed if there is no pay off for what was their focus of the game. The thing that brought me joy about this game may be different to what brings you joy.Kentucky Route Zero is more of an open ended road trip. It reminds me of American Gods if they'd never made it to the climactic ending and had instead simply travelled onwards meeting the local deities. In Kentucky route zero you don't meet God's but everyday people kind of caught in 'moments', usually trapped by some kind of debt or poverty. Mostly you don't save people and you're pretty passive other then deciding when to stop and when to go. I'm ok with this though, something about the humid black atmostphere just kind of works for me.You should check it out.

												I cannot recommend Kentucky Route Zero enough. The characters, environments, and music create a great, creepy, intriguing atmosphere that has always left me wanting more. If point-n-clicks aren't your thing, $25 is probably steep. It has gone on sale for at least half that, so you might wait if you're on the fence.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												An absolutely wonderful game. While the gameplay is pretty minimal and consists mostly of walking, examining objects and talking to NPCs, the story and the atmosphere are unlike anything you've experienced before. You know how during a dream you often see familiar everyday stuff mixed with surreal weirdness? Well, Kentucky Route Zero is exactly like that, except for the fact that during a dream you're usually not aware of the weirdness, and in this game it is right before your eyes and makes the game incredibly engrossing to play.The game is mostly a linear story-driven experience with a number of optional locations to visit, some of which appear as fully realized scenes, some as text adventures. During the game you get to make choices that change the narrative in subtle ways (like, for example, defining the main character's past in one of the dialogues), and even if the consequences of those choices aren't always immediately apparent, they become more and more meaningful the longer you play. Don't expect to cause any major changes (at least not in the first two Acts), but it's still nice to be able to personalize your playthrough and connect with the characters better.The art style is gorgeous as you can probably see from the screenshots. It's one of those games where you can take a screenshot at any moment and it will serve great as a wallpaper. The game has a stylized "aliased" look and it's a big part of the game's charm, but if you despise jaggies with passion you can force anti-aliasing in your graphics card drivers.The soundtrack is incredibly beautiful, both the ambient music and the songs by The Bedquilt Ramblers. It's the one of the main reasons Kentucky Route Zero is so atmospheric and you won't be able to get some of these tunes out of your head for weeks.As of today four Acts have been released, all of them fantastic as far as I'm concerned. I do wish the developers would release them at a quicker pace, but if they require more time to maintain this level of quality then I can live with it. Even if the final Act takes another 2 years I feel like I've already gotten my money's worth.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Only 4/5 episodes are out, and given the time between releases, we might never see episode 5. That being said, this game is still worth playing and enjoying as is. The atmosphere is unique and engaging, and works with the sparse game mechanics. It paints a compelling, dream-like picture of decaying Appalachia with surreal and humorous events, as well as sparse but effective music choices. Each episode is one to two hours long and best enjoyed in one sitting, preferably with a glass of bourbon and a relaxed frame of mind.
